Food and Digestive Cancer Chapter 1 Introduction

Food and Digestive Cancer Myles Ingram and Colin Payne-Rogers 2020-12-15 Chapter 1 Introduction Digestive system cancer, also known as gastrointestinal cancer, is one of the most prevalent forms of cancer in the US today. However, the number of gastrointestinal cancers has been decreasing over the years. Some researchers believe that population wide changes in diet, such as more fruit and vegetables being consumed, contributed to this decrease in digestive system cancer incidence. Nutritional content of diet and calorie consumption has been shown to be related to the onset of digestive system cancer, but Does a population-level increase in consumption (calories) relate to population-level increases in digestive cancer incidence? What about the nutritional content of food being eaten? Does a greater proportion of sugar or meat coincide with higher cancer incidence? Is there a relationship between cancer incidence and cancer mortality? For instance, with higher incidence does treatment get better? Or, does incidence lead to a load on oncology units, decreasing quality of care?
Chapter 2 Data sources 2.1 Data collection 2.2 Data Overview 2.3 Data Issues

Chapter 2 Data sources 2.1 Data collection For this project, we are using 3 different data sources: Male and female digestive system cancer mortality across 9 SEER cancer regristries for each year from 2000-2017, Male and female digestive system cancer incidence across 9 SEER cancer registries for each year from 2000-2017, and average daily per capita calorie intake from 1970-2017 for major and minor food groups in the US. Digestive system cancer includes stomach, gallbladder, colorectal (CRC), pancreatic, liver and esophageal cancers. These data sources were collected by Myles Ingram. The SEER digestive system cancer data sets were collected using SEER *Stat, a statistical software used to access SEER Research Data and produce statistics of cancer on a population. The digestive cancer incidence and mortatlity data was taken from a database that included 18 SEER registries, which represents 27.8% of the U.S. Population. This database was chosen because it represented the largest U.S. percentage of the population from different areas of the country so that our analysis could be more representative of the entire U.S. population. The average daily calorie intake data was downloaded from the USDA’s Food Availabity (Per Capita) Data System. The data set is used to approximate the actual consumption of food on a national level. The data we used was loss-adjusted meaning food spoilage, late waste, etc. was included in the creation of the data to more closely resemble actual consumption. 2.2 Data Overview The SEER digestive cancer incidence spreadsheet contains 5 variables and 54 rows The variables include Year, Gender, Rate per 100,000 persons (number of people who contracted digestive cancer out of every 100,000 persons), Cases (total number of cancer cases in given year), and total US population in that year. SEER digestive cancer mortality spreadsheet contains 5 variables and 54 rows The variables include Year, Gender, Rate per 100,000 persons (number of people who contracted digestive cancer out of every 100,000 persons), Cases (total number of cancer cases in given year), and total US population in that year. Average daily calorie intake data includes 8 different spreadsheets. Each spreadsheet has 48 rows, one row per year. The totals spreadsheet gives the total average calorie intake for each major food group which includes meat/protein, dairy, fruit, vegatables, flour/cereal products, added fats/oils/dairy fats, added sugar/sweeteners, and total calorie intake. Each food group has a seperate spreadsheet that breaks down the foods and calorie intakes of each food inside the category. 2.3 Data Issues One issue for the SEER data is that the entire U.S. is not included in the analysis only 18 SEER regristries from around the U.S. For the USDA data, calorie intakes for certain food types are missing within the data for certain years. This issues is especially prevelent for added fatss and oils and dairy fats category.
Chapter 3 Data transformation 3.1 Digestive Cancer Incidence 3.2 Digestive Cancer Mortality 3.3 Food Consumption 3.4 Write Out Data

Chapter 3 Data transformation The goal of this markdown file, as a draft, is to load raw project data from file and save that data in a form more conducive to future analyses. This format will change when draft chapters are combined into a final book. The raw data for the project consists of two .csv files and one .xls file. Each .csv corresponds to digestive system cancer incidence and digestive system cancer mortality, respectively, for the years 2000 to 2017. The .xls file contains information on per capita consumption from the years 1970 to the present. 3.1 Digestive Cancer Incidence Load the .csv data from file, remove summary rows whose first column contains 2000-2017 or whose values are a combination of the Male and Female data, and rename the columns. ## Year Sex V3 V4 V5 ## 1 2000 Male 113.0 35155 38920309 ## 2 2000 Female 75.2 31172 39968538 ## 3 2001 Male 113.9 36096 39367815 ## 4 2001 Female 74.4 31257 40391287 ## 5 2002 Male 111.1 36165 39740835 3.2 Digestive Cancer Mortality Load the .csv data from file, remove summary rows whose first column contains 2000-2017 or whose values are a combination of the Male and Female data, and rename the columns. ## Year Sex V3 V4 V5 ## 1 2000 Male 72.4 22469 38920309 ## 2 2000 Female 44.1 18307 39968538 ## 3 2001 Male 72.1 22813 39367815 ## 4 2001 Female 42.9 18062 40391287 ## 5 2002 Male 70.1 22736 39740835 3.3 Food Consumption The tidyverse readxl package is used to parse the .xls data. Chapter 4 Missing values Example of how the Missing data section will be done for fats spreadsheet, which has missing data and sugars data which does not have missing data 4.1 Fats ## Light Cream Heavy Cream Beef Tallow Half and Half Margarine Lard Shortening Salad and Cooking Oils ## 18 18 16 16 7 7 7 7 ## Other Added Fats X1 Year Butter Sour Cream Cream Cheese Eggnog ## 7 0 0 0 0 0 0 ## NOTE: The following pairs of variables appear to have the same missingness pattern. ## Please verify whether they are in fact logically distinct variables. ## [,1] [,2] ## [1,] "Margarine" "Lard" ## [2,] "Margarine" "Shortening" ## [3,] "Margarine" "Salad and Cooking Oils" ## [4,] "Margarine" "Other Added Fats" ## [5,] "Lard" "Shortening" ## [6,] "Lard" "Salad and Cooking Oils" ## [7,] "Lard" "Other Added Fats" ## [8,] "Shortening" "Salad and Cooking Oils" ## [9,] "Shortening" "Other Added Fats" ## [10,] "Salad and Cooking Oils" "Other Added Fats" ## [11,] "Light Cream" "Heavy Cream" ## [1] "Year" "Butter" "Margarine" "Lard" "Beef Tallow" "Shortening" "Salad and Cooking Oils" ## [8] "Other Added Fats" "Light Cream" "Half and Half" "Heavy Cream" "Sour Cream" "Cream Cheese" "Eggnog" 4.2 Sugars ## X1 Year Cane and Beet Sugar High Fructose Corn Syrup Glucose Dextrose Edible Syrups ## 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 ## Honey ## 0 ## [1] "Year" "Butter" "Margarine" "Lard" "Beef Tallow" "Shortening" "Salad and Cooking Oils" ## [8] "Other Added Fats" "Light Cream" "Half and Half" "Heavy Cream" "Sour Cream" "Cream Cheese" "Eggnog" For fats, it seems that the pattern of missing data starts in 2000 for some food types and others the missing data starts in 2010. It seems like either the fats database is updated every decade or added fats is gradually being excluded from this dataset. All values are present in the sugars spreadsheet
